discussion.content:
https://pubs.opengroup.org/architecture/togaf9-doc/arch/chap42.html

An Architecture Compliance review is a scrutiny of the compliance of a specific project against established architectural criteria, spirit, and business objectives. A formal process for such reviews normally forms the core of an Enterprise Architecture Compliance strategy.

Usually is performed via various Architecture Compliance Review Checklists.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following best describes an Architecture Compliance Review?

choices.B: A review of the plans for enterprise transformation
choices.E: A review of the baseline and target architectures to identity gaps
choices.A: A review of an architecture project against established criteria and business objectives
choices.C: A review of an organization's ability to share information and services
choices.D: A review of the readiness of an organization to accept change

choices.C: To define an IT Strategy that maps out the technology infrastructure
choices.A: To create a roadmap that describes the evolution of the architecture over time
choices.D: To allocate the resources needed to implement the architecture project
choices.B: To prepare a Solution Architecture for the enterprise

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a key objective of Phase A of the TOGAF ADM?

discussion.content: E. To articulate an Architecture Vision

Selected Answer: E
To articulate architecture vision

questions.question_text: Complete the sentence. The Architecture Landscape is divided into three levels, Capability, Segment, and ____________.

discussion.content:
37.2 Architecture Landscape
The Architecture Landscape holds architectural views of the state of the enterprise at particular points in time. 3 Levels:

1. "Strategic Architectures" (see Part I, 3.74 Strategic Architecture) show a long-term summary view of the entire enterprise. Strategic Architectures provide an organizing framework for operational and change activity and allow for direction setting at an executive level.
2. "Segment Architectures" (see Part I, 3.64 Segment Architecture) provide more detailed operating models for areas within an enterprise. Segment Architectures can be used at the program or portfolio level to organize and operationally align more detailed change activity.
3. "Capability Architectures" (see Part I, 3.31 Capability Architecture) show in a more detailed fashion how the enterprise can support a particular unit of capability. Capability Architectures are used to provide an overview of current capability, target capability, and capability increments and allow for individual work packages and projects to be grouped within managed portfolios and programs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a re-usable artifact that is used to create architecture models addressing stakeholder concerns?

discussion.content:
40. Architectural Artifacts:
An "architecture viewpoint" is a specification of the conventions for a particular kind of
architecture view. It can also be called the definition or schema for that kind of architecture view.

Architecture viewpoints are "generic", and can be stored in libraries "for re-use"; an
architecture view is always specific to the architecture for which it is created.

questions.question_text: Complete the sentence. TOGAF describes the role of an Architecture Contract as_______.

choices.B: a plan to ensure that architecture information is communicated to the right stakeholders at the right time
choices.A: an agreement between development partners and sponsors on the architecture deliverables
choices.D: a timeline showing progression from the Baseline Architecture to the Target Architecture
choices.C: a set of general rules and guidelines to support development of the enterprise architecture

discussion.content:
Architecture Contracts are the joint agreements between development partners and sponsors on
the deliverables, quality, and fitness-for-purpose of an architecture. Successful implementation
of these agreements will be delivered through effective Architecture Governance
